Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Situation2: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Story:
I stared at my phone, torn between two text threads. My sister had just messaged, “Movie night at my place? Bring Alex!” She always wanted us to include each other, to build that sense of family and respect. But Alex, my boyfriend, was still upset after our argument about splitting rent and groceries. He’d barely spoken to me all week, and I knew he expected me to help resolve things, to talk it out and not just brush it aside.

I could hear my sister’s laughter in my mind, picturing her disappointment if I showed up alone or, worse, didn’t come at all. But I also felt the weight of Alex’s silence, the tension in our apartment, and the unspoken hope that tonight we’d finally sit down and work through our issues. My heart pounded as I typed and erased messages, feeling pulled in two directions—wanting to be the supportive sister who brings everyone together, and the caring girlfriend who doesn’t run from hard conversations. I just sat there, phone in hand, unable to choose which role to let down.
